properties.Title: Update To Civil Emergency Alert Issued By Government Of Saskatchewan
properties.Summary:
Description: Update for the Civil Emergency Alert issued by the Government of Saskatchewan. The state of emergency in Saskatchewan remains in effect. UPDATE: Phase 2 of Re-Open Saskatchewan became effective May 19, 2020. All Public Health Orders continue to apply during the implementation of Phase 2 Re-Open Saskatchewan. Testing is now available to anyone working outside the home, who desires a test, including those currently working or returning to work as part of the Re-Open Saskatchewan plan. Avoid unnecessary travel and stay home if you are sick or symptomatic. Public and private gatherings, inside and outside, are limited to more no more than 10 people and physical distancing by at least two metres from others is to be applied. Wash your hands often. Together, we are reducing the risk. We can pull together by staying apart.
Expires: 2020-06-01T17:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre, 2020-05-25T16:02:21-06:00, BFA658EA-A827-959E-81E1-2A18B4A13712
Area: Province of Saskatchewan
properties.Author: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Smoke from a forest fire near the Frankville area of Antigonish County is causing a reduction in visibility and air quality over areas in its vicinity and downwind towards Highway 104 and into western Cape Breton. Locations: Frankville and surrounding areas, including downwind areas in eastern Antigonish county and southern Inverness County. Short range wind forecast: south to southwest 20 to 40 km/h, diminishing to 10- 20 later this evening. Remarks: Latest reports Monday evening indicate the fire is considered out of control and has consumed nearly 200 hectares. More information will be provided as it become available. ### Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-05-26T16:28:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness, 2020-05-26T00:29:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3337258517.2020
Area: Antigonish County, Inverness County - south of Mabou
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Smoke from a forest fire near Savvies River is causing a reduction in air quality due to smoke in its vicinity and areas downwind to the east and northeast. Locations: Savvies River to Rogersville and vicinity. Satellite imagery shows smoke stretching eastward over an area roughly between Richibiucto and Miramichi all the way to the coast. Short range wind forecast: Southwesterly 20 km/h with gusts to 40, diminishing to Southwest 15 km/h overnight tonight. . Remarks: Latest reports indicate the forest fire is still out of control and covering an estimated area of 200 hectares. ### Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-05-26T15:09:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the New Brunswick Department of Environment and Local Government, the New Brunswick Department of Health, 2020-05-25T23:10:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3467780702.2020
Area: Stanley - Doaktown - Blackville Area, Kent County, Kouchibouguac National Park, Miramichi and area
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the New Brunswick Department of Environment and Local Government, the New Brunswick Department of Health

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hot daytime temperatures expected Tuesday through Thursday. Daytime highs in the low thirties are expected however night temperatures will drop below 17, giving some relief to the heat. The regions are being monitored for a possible heat warning however at this time the main concern is afternoon high temperatures. Humidex values may also be in the high thirties. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-26T11:14:47-00:00

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Smoke from a forest fire is causing a reduction in visibility and air quality over areas in its vicinity and downwind towards Highway 104. Locations: Old Mulgrave road in the Havre Boucher, Frankville, and surrounding areas. Short range wind forecast: south to southwest 30 to 50 km/h, diminishing to 20 this evening. properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 35 are expected for the next 3 days. First heat event of the season Tuesday through Thursday. High daytime temperatures in the low thirties are expected Tuesday afternoon and temperatures are forecast to be similar Wednesday and Thursday. Humidex values in the mid to upper thirties are also expected. A cold front will bring a few showers and lower temperatures to Eastern Ontario late Thursday or Thursday night. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-26T20:41:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-26T04:42:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0624590531.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Unseasonably warm weather expected Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. Time span: starting Tuesday afternoon. Maximum temperature: 30 degrees Celsius (Humidex 30 to 34), with slightly higher values expected Wednesday and Thursday. Locations: New Brunswick (cooler temperatures for coastal communities). Remarks: Temperatures are expected to rise during the day on Tuesday. Warmer and more humid conditions are expected Wednesday and Thursday. A cold front will bring a return to normal temperatures for the start of the weekend. Reduce your risk. Schedule outdoor activities during the coolest parts of the day. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBstorm. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-26T17:22:26-00:00

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing damaging wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Severe thunderstorms are possible this afternoon or tonight. ### Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.
Expires: 2020-05-26T05:03:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-25T19:40:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0609541939.2020
Area: Nakina - Aroland - Pagwa, Manitouwadge - Hornepayne, Fraserdale - Pledger Lake, Kapuskasing - Hearst - Smooth Rock Falls, Little Abitibi - Kesagami Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage frost-sensitive fruit trees and vegetable plants. Frost may damage crops in some areas. Minimum temperatures: +4 (cooler in low lying areas). Locations: Prince Edward Island. Time span: overnight into Tuesday morning. Remarks: Patchy frost is expected to form as clear skies and light winds coincide with cool temperatures, especially in low lying areas. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-26T10:35:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-25T18:36:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2811296479.2020
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and large hail. Scattered showers and thunderstorms have developed over areas southwest of Chibougamau. Some of these thunderstorms may produce hail along with strong wind gusts. These thunderstorms will weaken through the evening. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Locally heavy rain is also possible. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-26T08:19:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-25T22:55:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4112343208.2020
Area: Chibougamau, Gouin Reservoir area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warmer temperatures expected starting Tuesday. A much warmer airmass is forecast to move into the area Tuesday with high temperatures expected to reach between 30 and 33 Celsius Tuesday, Wednesday and possibly Thursday. Corresponding humidex values will range from 35 to 38. Overnight lows are forecast to be between 18 and 22 Celsius. Cooler temperatures are forecast for the end of the week. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-26T11:16:40-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: First heat event of the season today and Wednesday. High daytime temperatures near 30 are expected this afternoon and again on Wednesday. Humidex values in the mid to upper thirties are also expected. The heat is expected to end on Thursday with the arrival of showers and cooler air. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
